Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2009 02:53AM LizinKS wrote: What a pretty woman you are with a wonderful smile. I am about 15-16 months out from radiation and I still have tenderness where my two sentinal nodes were removed as well as in the area where radiation is concentrated. I still feel discomfort on one side that could be a slight lymphodema.I asked my radiation oncologist and he says that it's normal. (I have a friend who's a couple of years out who says she's still tender.)Still,I think,as the ever-wise shirlann suggested, if you are very uncomfortable, check with your doctor to make sure it isn't costochondritis or lymphodema (which a compression sleeve might help.) You lost a number of lymph glands and a pretty large mass of breast tissue in surgery. I find eating too much salt or being dehydrated can aggravate discomfort. I hope you have a physician who will listen to your complaints and try to help you. Best wishes, Liz in KS

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2009 12:01AM LizinKS wrote: No chemo before rads,but thought I was feeling fatigue within the first week or so. Turns out I had low potassium, causing me not only fatigue but dizziness and nausea. I think that happened mostly due to a miserably hot and muggy July, drying medications, and eating less than my normal diet following the stress of diagnosis and surgery. Potassium-rich foods and keeping hydrated helped solved the symptoms. I had 33 treatments, including eight boosts. The boosts made my breast and surrounding area very sore and swollen. Like some others above,I didn't really feel tired until after the treatments ended. Part of that fatigue was the emotional letdown that follows treatment. The last treatment was Aug. 25,2008. Six months later,my energy level is back to normal. My effected breast is a "new normal", but thanks goodness,cancer-free. You're in my thoughts and prayers. There really is an end to this. Plan something special to celebrate the end. In the meantime,pamper yourself and eat healthy and drink plenty of liquids!
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2009 11:42PM LizinKS wrote: Miriam,I'm so sorry about your bad news. You're so wise to keep your sense of humor,which helps in the darkest of times, and take each day as it comes. You're right to keep to your routine and read and watch what one SF Bay Area radio personality with a sultry voice called terribly.tacky.tabloid.trash (periods included for emphasis on each word)! Glad your docs are supportive. Don't be afraid to ask you family for extra help when your energy begins to flag. Please know you are in everyone's thoughts and prayers of many spread across the U.S. Caring thoughts,love and hugs! LizinKS
Posts.Title: Horrible News re Swollen Groin Node mshalto mshalto

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2011 12:45AM LizinKS wrote: Dear Blue Willow Sky, I sympathize with your going through rads during the sticky summer months. I am now nearing three years out from completing my rads in late August 2008 while living in Lawrence,KS - another great university town with icky,sticky summers. I'm not sure whether it was the rads or not, but I found I would often feel weak and nauseous getting out in the heat following a treatment. I found it did help to drink juices that had potassium in them - V-8 was the best - or eating a banana or citrus fruit. Just make sure you're well-hydrated - always, but especially when your body is under stress during radiation. Hope you are blessed with as great a radiation oncologist as I had. Know you will be in my thoughts. Just take it one day at a time, and make sure you do something enjoyable for yourself every day - no matter how small - a good book or movie or fun TV show. Hugs, Liz
Posts.Title: JUNE 2011 RADS bluewillowskys duckyb1

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2011 12:51AM LizinKS wrote: Rohana, What you likely have is radiation pneumonia - which can happen up to six months after treatment. I did not have it, but it's not uncommon. It could also be caused by allergies this time of year or even a respiratory infection. Be sure to mention to your radiation oncologist!!! If the cough gets too bad, the doc could give you prescription with a cough suppressant. But do be sure it isn't an infection other than radiation pneumonia.
Posts.Title: JUNE 2011 RADS bluewillowskys duckyb1

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2012 02:41AM LizinKS wrote: Know you are scared, but the lumpectomy really doesn't cause much pain. They will also remove two sentinal lymph nodes, which will be sent to the hospital's pathology lab while you are still on the operating table. The surgeon will be able to tell you a lot about your cancer right after surgery. There will be a second,final pathology report that will give you complete information. The good news is if the sentinal nodes - the first nodes that a cancer might travel to - are benign, there is a statistical chance of 95 percent that all the other axilliary (underarm) nodes are also clear of cancer. This is quite an improvement from 50 years ago when removing all nodes plus the whole breast was standard treatmemt. I found I had quite a bit more post-surgical pain from the removal of my two sentinal nodes than the lumpectomy area of my breast. Another tip is to have a second person with you on visits to the various physicians involved in your care - particularly at the beginning.That way, you will have a second set of ears hearing what the doctors have to say. Keeping you in my thoughts and prayers! I am four years out and remain cancer-free.
Posts.Title: Overwhelmed Lettiegonz LittleMelons

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 04:45AM LizinKS wrote: Dear Mary/Texas Rose, I,too,am so sorry that you received such unwanted news.  Of course, you're scared! Know you are in my prayers as well as you go through the coming weeks and months. Seek out all the support you can from family, friends,clergy and church members, if you are a religious person, your physicians and medical techs and nurses - and online friends,as well. They will help get you through. Plus you will find out that more people in your circle of friends and acquaintances than you ever imagined are themselves cancer survivors or relatives of survivors! Support of friends and family kept my husband and me going.  Just take this journey a day at a time, a week at a time and know life really will return to normal before too long.Do something you like each day during this journey and plan a reward when this journey through cancer treatment is complete. I bought tickets for a fall Tina Turner (the ultimate survivor) concert four days before my surgery last May 30. She was fierce and wonderful!  We are rooting for you!

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2009 03:20AM LizinKS wrote: I just joined a women's fitness center. On a very recent visit,I asked her if there is any exercise activity I should avoid. I only had two sentinal nodes removed-both benign. She said that I should avoid lifting weights over my head since that can cause some lymphodema even in cases like mine. I would ask your oncologist before doing any weightlifting.

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2010 01:01AM LizinKS wrote: To mawhinney: I had an Oncotype DX score of 30, but opted not to do chemo. I had a lumpectomy for a <1 cm IDC in late May of 2008. I was 61 at the time. I had clean margins, was ER/PR+,HER2-negative and two clear sentinal  nodes. Upon my first visit, my oncologist, spoke about the Oncotype DX test to determine my chance for distant recurrence. I was scared to death when I heard about this, as I thought my pathology would indicate chemo was not necessary.My onc explained that chemo would involve two rounds of four treatments - about eight weeks of time,  and that the chemo would be a preventative measure.. The Oncotype score came back within 10 days and it was 30, just one point below being in the high range! A score of 30 meant that I would have a 20% chance of recurrence (plus or minus five percent). Prophylactic chemo would bring the percentage down to 8-12 %.  I chose not to do the chemo, considering my age and the potential for damage done by chemo drugs. Also, my husband, a physicist, and I thought there still is no explanation of other factors beyond genetic markers that would explain why recurrence happens in 20% of women and not in the other 80%. Age and tumor size were parameters that were not factors that affected a woman's chances of recurrence. It appears at the present stage of research, genetic markers are consistantly more predictive. However, were the patients who had recurrence overweight, alcoholic, did thery smoke,of a certain race,etc? These and other factors have yet to be included in the research. Just seems like a crap shot. Also,chemo can sometimes cause blood cancers,heart damage,and neuropathy, and more. Were I 31 years old instead of 61, I quite likely would have done chemo. It was such a hard decision, but the right one for me. I completed 33 radiation treamentw in late August 2008. I began Arimidex in early Sept. 2008. With the Arimidex, I have only a little extra stiffness beyond my usual osteoarthritis in the morning..I remain cancer-free almost 2 1 /2 years later. I have made improvements in my eating habits and exercise and hope I will continue to do well.Cancer is a complicated,frightening disease. I am just grateful that miy very deep-seated tumor was found by mammogram as neither my gp or I found any lumps with breast exams. Hope further research will make the decision easier and the genomic testing more definitive.  Best wishes to all of you facing this decision whether or not to do preventative chemo.You are in my prayers.
